We haven't done much research on how ivermectin works, must confess. But here's a search that seems to confirm ivermectin helps with brain inflammation:

https://www.startpage.com/do/search?q=does+ivermectin+reduce+brain+inflammatin&segment=startpage.brave

We also asked Grok: Does ivermectin reduce brain inflammation. Answer:

Yes, preclinical studies show ivermectin reduces brain inflammation in models like ischemia-reperfusion, EAE (MS-like), and epilepsy by lowering cytokines (e.g., TNF-Î±, IL-1Î²), oxidative stress, and inflammatory cell infiltration. Human evidence is limited; consult a doctor.

Key studies:

- Neuroprotective effects in rats: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37755672/

- EAE modulation in mice: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10753-023-01829-y

- Epilepsy review: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/epi4.13107

George
7 oct.

Aluminum and silicon are abundant in many mineral clays naturally.

"The tetrahedral sheet is carrying negative charge due to the isomorphous substitution of Al3+ in place of Si4+ generating the charge deficiency in tetrahedral sheet. Common tetrahedral cations are Si4+, Al3+, and Fe3+." and "The main dominating atoms in octahedral sheets are Al3+ or Mg2+ surrounded by six oxygen atoms or hydroxyl group give rise to eight sided building block known as octahedron. Since, octahedral sheet are present in two forms: dioctahedral or trioctahedral sheet."

see web link for more information on this subject

https://www.intechopen.com/chapters/76780

A Midwestern Doctor
6 oct.

I was agahast and still somewhat in disbelief that someone of his stature I followed for years misinterpreted that information to that degree or missed that it proved DMSO is extremely safe for mitochondria. I've tried contacting them numerous times to explain this but I have not heard back.

The basic issue is that most drugs and substances (roughly 90%) kill cells immediately at a 1% concentration, at around 0.001% (and often much lower if they are more toxic) inhibit their growth, and at far lower concentrations show signs of cellular stress (ie. mitochondrial damage).

When you consume any drug or substance, it massively dilutes in the body and is typically around 0.001% or much much lower, with many commonly used drugs killing cells at 0.000001% or lower. This is particularly true with DMSO as due to it's ability to spread throughout the body, it rapidly dillutes to a much lower concentration.

What he found was that DMSO is sometimes damaging to cells at a 1-5% concentration (which requires drinking roughly a liter of pure DMSO each day to maintain whereas most people drink 1-4 teapspoons). What this means in plain english is that it is dramatically less toxic than any vitamin on the market.

Cell studies are used to screen drugs for potential toxicities early in the developmental stage, and there is a general range of what concentration can be used. In the case of DMSO, it's toxicity begins to emerge at 5%, and when used in cryopreservation, the freezing allows it to be raised to 10% (or higher if another cryopreservant is mixed in). When you consider that most drugs and substances are lethal to cells at 0.01% (and often much lower levels), the whole thing is really shocking.

I use all the different types of vitamin C during the day. 1g Ascorbic acid with the Meth, 1 packet of Liv On liposomal in the morning 20 encapsulated liposomal through out the day till bed time and than 1 more packet of Liv On liposomal before bed. Don't expect you body to accept that much Ascorbic or sodium Ascorbic acid without having several bowel movements through out the day as it is cleared through you kidneys and bowels but the liposomal is absorbed by your fat cells and doesn't cause bowel problems so you might want to start off slow with the ascorbic acid and sodium ascorbic and use mostly liposomal as it is eaiser on your stomach. Using the Meth Blue is something you should start off with small doses like 5 to 8 drops until you see how your body reacts. There are many causes to look at, but I believe one of the causes not given any attention, and should be, is the use of MRI contrast which contains the heavy metal "gadolinium". Many people complain of "brain fog" soon after their injection. Mine has lasted for 8 years since I received my one and only injection of contrast. It imbeds in the brain, bone and tissue and according to a Japanese study, stays in the body for 126 years. There is no antidote to remove it, as there is no chelator strong enough to hold onto the Gd ions until excretion. It mainly just redistributes into other parts of the body. Gadolinium was first approved in 1988 and it seems since around that time, cases of dementia and Alzheimer's have steadily increased.

A few antidotal observations we experienced in my own family; my husband was on BP meds for years. His BP would spike and his cardiologist would tell him to temporarily up his dosage. He decided to try weaning himself off the BP meds and has found he now has normal BP. If it occasionally spikes, especially during stressful periods, he either takes a hot shower or goes out in the sun for 10 minutes and his BP drops 30-40 points back to normal. It made us wonder if the BP meds were designed to keep him dependent on them. For myself, I was prescribed a low dose BP med and decided to only take it as needed, rather than daily. So because I only take them as needed, I had an unfilled refill at the pharmacy. One day I got a call from the pharmacist telling me I had a refill that needed to be refilled. I told her I was only taking them as needed and I didn't need the refill. She admonished me and said they were supposed to be taken daily. I replied that my medication use was none of her business, that in my opinion pharmacies have become bigger drug cartels than the Columbian cartels and to never call me again.
